Article TiO2–x @C/MoO2 Schottky junction: Rational design and efficient charge separation for promoted photocatalytic performance Xiu-Qing Qiao a b * Chen Li a Zizhao Wang a Dongfang Hou a b Dong-Sheng Li a b * a College of Materials and Chemical Engineering, Key Laboratory of Inorganic Nonmetallic Crystalline and Energy Conversion Materials, China Three Gorges University, Yichang 443002, Hubei, China College of Materials and Chemical Engineering Key Laboratory of Inorganic Nonmetallic Crystalline and Energy Conversion Materials China Three Gorges University Yichang Hubei 443002 China College of Materials and Chemical Engineering, Key Laboratory of Inorganic Nonmetallic Crystalline and Energy Conversion Materials, China Three Gorges University, Yichang 443002, Hubei, China b Hubei Three Gorges Laboratory, Yichang 443007, Hubei, China Hubei Three Gorges Laboratory Yichang Hubei 443007 China Hubei Three Gorges Laboratory, Yichang 443007, Hubei, China * Corresponding author. Limited solar light harvesting, sluggish charge transfer kinetics, and inferior affinity for adsorbed hydrogen species (H*) severely restrict the photocatalytic hydrogen generation activity of TiO2 photocatalysts. Herein, we present a novel TiO2–x @C/MoO2 Schottky junction prepared via a simple one-step in situ phase-transition-regulation strategy. Crucially, the abundant oxygen vacancies in TiO2–x @C/MoO2 narrow the bandgap and introduce defects to improve the photoresponse. The strongly bonded carbon layer not only serves as a fast charge-transport channel to improve the interlayer charge transfer efficiency but also protects oxygen vacancies from oxidation. Moreover, the Schottky barrier effectively impairs the recombination of electrons and holes and promotes the utilization of photogenerated electrons. Furthermore, the MoO2 cocatalyst optimizes the Gibbs free energy for H2 evolution. As a result of the favorable synergy, the resulting TiO2–x @C/MoO2 presents a significantly enhanced photocatalytic H2 production rate of 506 μmol g−1 h−1 compared to those of TiO2–x and TiO2–x @C (125.5- and 15.8-times larger, respectively). Moreover, outstanding stability over 27 h was achieved because of the protection provided by the surface carbon layer. This ingenious design and facile synthetic strategy offer exciting avenues for the design of strongly coupled Schottky junction photocatalysts for efficient solar-to-chemical conversions. Graphical Abstract A novel TiO2-x @C/MoO2 Schottky junction with strong light absorption suppressed electron back transfer, and optimized H2 dissociation was realized via a simple one-step in situ phase-transition regulation strategy. Keywords Oxygen vacancy TiO2 MoO2 Carbon layer H2 evolution Schottky junction 1 Introduction Hydrogen energy is green and sustainable, having a high energy density of 143 MJ kg−1, making it promising for addressing the current energy and environmental crises [ 1 ]. Photocatalytic hydrogen evolution via water splitting is regarded as an optimal strategy to address this issue. Nevertheless, the pursuit of efficient photocatalysts is restricted by the poor light response and the inevitable recombination of photogenerated charge carriers [ 2 ]. Fortunately, over the past few decades, significant efforts have been devoted to optimizing activity by promoting light utilization and charge separation. For instance, defect engineering [ 3 ], heterojunction construction [ 4 ], and cocatalyst modification [ 5 ] have been reported to significantly enhance photocatalytic activity. In particular, cocatalyst loading is a potential strategy for constructing high-performance photocatalysts. Unfortunately, the electrons captured by the cocatalyst flow in reverse from the cocatalyst to the photocatalyst, weakening the charge separation efficiency. Furthermore, in a multicomponent photocatalytic system, the interfacial charge transfer kinetics between different components are critical for enhancing photocatalytic performance. Therefore, rationally designed photocatalysts with strong interfacial contact between various components and suppressed electron backflow are highly desirable for achieving efficient photocatalysis. Titanium dioxide (TiO2) is nontoxic, inexpensive, chemically stable, and highly active under ultraviolet light irradiation and is the most researched photocatalyst since the discovery of TiO2 photoanodes [ 6,7 ]. Unfortunately, inefficient visible-light absorption and fast charge recombination hinder its photocatalytic H2 evolution efficiency [ 8 ]. Nevertheless, TiO2 can oxidize pollutants such as tetracycline [ 9 ], dimethyl sulfide [ 10 ], and methyl orange [ 11 ] owing to the strong oxidation ability of the formed reactive oxygen species [ 12,13 ]. More recently, oxygen vacancies (OVs) have been reported to be effective in ameliorating the aforementioned issues facing photocatalysts [ 14 ]. OVs are positively charged and can attract negative charge, improving the local charge density and producing new local states or shallow donor levels below the conduction band (CB); this results in the narrowing of the band gap energy to increase the optical spectrum absorption [ 15,16 ]. In addition, the presence of surface OVs can improve surface reaction activity and contribute to molecular adsorption [ 17 ]. Nevertheless, the photoactivity for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is still unsatisfactory because of the restricted interfacial charge transfer kinetics in TiO2–x . Moreover, the surface OVs in the semiconductor are always thermodynamically unstable owing to unusual transformation modes [ 18 ], leading to the deterioration of photocatalytic activity [ 19 ]. Hence, the development of a stable TiO2−x photocatalyst using a simple and economical strategy remains challenging. The noble metal Pt is the current state-of-the-art cocatalyst for accelerating charge separation owing to its zero-approaching Gibbs free energy with H atoms, but its scarcity and instability restrict its practical application [ 20 ]. Therefore, the development of nonprecious metal cocatalysts to accelerate the practical application of photocatalysts has become a hot topic [ 21,22 ]. Metallic molybdenum dioxide (MoO2) semiconductors are attracting increasing attention because of their high conductivity [ 23 ] and chemical stability [ 24 ] as electrocatalysts [ 25 ], pseudocapacitors [ 26,27 ], and lithium-ion batteries [ 28 ]. Theoretical calculations show that MoO2 has a Gibbs free energy (ΔG H*) close to that of Pt, as well as a large work function [ 29,30 ], implying that MoO2 is a potential cocatalyst for photocatalytic H2 evolution. Very recently, several studies have reported a boost in photocatalytic activity by utilizing MoO2 cocatalysts [ 31–34 ]. However, complicated multistep assembly methods were used in these studies, which resulted in poor interfacial contact between the different components, impeding charge transfer and separation. Further, the inevitable aggregation of MoO2 nanoparticles (NPs) at elevated synthetic temperatures restricts the exposure of the active sites of O and Mo terminal atoms [ 35 ]. From this perspective, exploring a feasible one-step method for constructing a photocatalyst system with a tight interface between the photocatalyst and well-dispersed MoO2 cocatalyst is crucial for the realization of an outstanding photocatalyst. Here, we report an ingenious one-step in situ phase-transition-regulation strategy for constructing a novel TiO2–x @C/MoO2 Schottky junction. A rationally designed Schottky junction was integrated with abundant OVs, a conductive carbon layer, and a metallic cocatalyst to promote the light response and charge-transfer dynamics of the photocatalyst. In this case, the abundant OVs in TiO2–x can significantly improve light absorption and decrease ΔG H*, whereas the MoO2 cocatalyst, which has a strong electron extraction capacity, promotes electron transfer from TiO2–x to the cocatalyst. Strongly coupled conductive carbon serves as an electron mediator to accelerate the charge transfer from TiO2–x to MoO2 through chemical bonds. In addition, the carbon layer coated on the surface of TiO2–x protects the OVs from corrosion by dissolved oxygen. As expected, the resultant Schottky junction promoted photocatalytic hydrogen generation activity and stability. Therefore, the developed one-step in situ phase-transition-regulation strategy provides a feasible synthetic route for forming a strong interface-coupled Schottky junction photocatalyst. 2 Experimental Citric acid (C6H8O7) and ammonium heptamolybdate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Commercial Degussa P25 powder was used as received. 2.1 Synthesis of the TiO2–x@C/MoO2 photocatalyst Typically, 2 g of P25 powder, 1 g of citric acid (C6H8O7), and ammonium heptamolybdate [(NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O] were mixed by grinding. The mixture was then calcined at 800 °C for 2 h under an Ar atmosphere. The dark-gray products were then collected, and the resulting samples are denoted TiO2–x @C/MoO2-n (TCM-n), where n represents the mass amount of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O. For comparison, the control sample, TiO2–x /MoO2, was prepared by mixing TiO2–x with MoO2. The TiO2–x /MoO y sample was obtained in the absence of citric acid, whereas TiO2–x was prepared by annealing pure P25 under the same conditions. 2.2 Material characterization X-ray diffractometry (XRD) measurements were performed using a Philips X’ Pert Pro diffractometer to identify phases and crystal structures. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were obtained to understand the microstructure using a JOLJSM-7500F. More detailed information was obtained using transmission electron microscopy (TEM; Tecnai G2 F30). Raman spectra were obtained at 532-nm excitation using a Raman spectrometer. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy was performed to confirm the presence of OVs using an A300-10/12 spectrometer (Bruker, USA). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to reveal the element/valence state information and was performed on the ESCALAB 250Xi. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were acquired on Microtrac BEL automatic three-station specific surface and pore distribution BELSORP-Max instrument. Ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV-vis DRS) was used to determine the photoresponsiveness, as measured using a UV-2550 spectrometer. Photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy can be used to reveal the charge recombination behavior, and PL spectra were obtained under 370 nm excitation using an F97 Pro. The lifetimes of the charge carriers were determined by fitting time-resolved fluorescence lifetime curves. The superoxide radical (•O2 −) and hydroxyl radical (•OH) radicals were quantified using EPR spectroscopy (A300-10/12, Bruker) after illuminating a mixture of photocatalyst and 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO). Photoelectrochemical performance was evaluated using an electrochemical workstation (CHI660E). The working electrode was prepared by loading the photocatalyst onto a glassy carbon electrode (GCE). The electrolyte was 0.5 mol L−1 Na2SO4. Transient photocurrent response (TPR) curves were obtained under irradiation with a 300-W Xe lamp. A Ag/AgCl reference electrode was used to obtain the Mott-Schottky (M-S) curves. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was conducted to analyze the charge transfer dynamics [ 36 ]. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was used to evaluate HER performance. 2.3 Photocatalytic experiments Photocatalytic H2 production in the presence of a TCM Schottky junction was evaluated using Perfect equipment with a 300-W Xenon lamp as the light source. Briefly, 20 mg of the photocatalyst was measured and poured into a 250-mL Pyrex reactor. Subsequently, an 8% lactic acid solution was used as the sacrificial agent. The system was subjected to vacuum before the xenon lamp source was switched on. The H2 evolution rate was determined using a GC-9700 gas chromatograph using N2 carrier gas. The stabilities of the photocatalysts were assessed by degassing the solutions every 3 h for 27 h. Tetracycline (TC; 10 mg L−1) and Cr(VI) (20 mg L−1) solutions were selected as model contaminants to estimate the enhanced charge separation at the TCM Schottky junction. A 50-mL solution of each contaminant was prepared in advance. Typically, 5 mg of photocatalyst was mixed ultrasonically with the contaminant and stirred in the dark for 40 min. Subsequently, the TC or K2Cr2O7 solution was degraded in the photoreactor under light irradiation. Three milliliters of the suspension were centrifuged every 10 min, and the resulting solution was tested by UV-visible absorption spectroscopy to determine its degradation rate. Intermediate substances were investigated using liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC-MS, 1290 Infinity II+6470B). 2.4 Theoretical calculations OV-rich TiO2–x was simulated by removing one oxygen atom from the supercell. The Vienna Ab Initio Simulation Package (VASP) was used to model the materials at the atomic scale. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) Perdew-Burke- Ernzerhof exchange-correlation functional was used for the structural calculations. The cut-off energy was set to 500 eV. 3 Results and discussion A TiO2–x @C/MoO2 Schottky junction was fabricated via a one-step in situ phase-transition-regulation strategy, as illustrated in Fig. 1 . As shown, citric acid, which has C=O functional groups, plays a triple role in the formation of the TiO2–x @C/MoO2 Schottky junction by inhibiting the phase transformation of anatase-TiO2 to rutile-TiO2, thus improving the OV concentration and generating metallic MoO2. Furthermore, the carbon generated from the in situ thermal decomposition of citric acid not only serves as a conductive channel for charge carrier separation but also protects the internal material to improve stability. 3.1 Sample characterization The indispensable role of citric acid in the in situ phase transition strategy is evidenced by the XRD results shown in Fig. 2 . The diffraction peaks of the P25 sample fit well with the characteristic peaks of anatase and rutile TiO2. In the absence of citric acid, anatase TiO2 is completely transformed into the rutile phase owing to the high-temperature phase transition [ 37,38 ]. Here, the obtained sample has few oxygen vacancies and is labeled TiO2–x (discussed later). With the addition of citric acid, anatase-TiO2 was observed in the TiO2–x @C sample, indicating that citric acid can inhibit the phase TiO2 transformation. After the mixture of P25 and MoO2 was annealed, only rutile TiO2 was detected in the XRD pattern (Fig. S1), further supporting this point. The formation of MoO2 in the TCM sample was confirmed by the appearance of characteristic peaks of tetragonal MoO2 (JCPDS 02–0422). Thus, it should be noted that citric acid plays a vital role in the formation of MoO2 NPs. After annealing ammonium heptamolybdate without citric acid, Mo4O11 and MoO2 were formed (Fig. S2(a)), whereas only metallic MoO2 was obtained after the introduction of citric acid (Fig. S2(b)). Furthermore, rutile-TiO2 and MoO y (a mixture of MoO3 and MoO2) were generated by annealing a mixture of P25 and ammonium heptamolybdate in the absence of citric acid. These results indicate that citric acid not only suppresses the phase transition of anatase-rutile TiO2 but also promotes the formation of reduced metallic MoO2 NPs. In addition, the much weaker XRD patterns of the TCM samples further indicate the presence of oxygen vacancies [ 39 ]. The enlarged (24°–30°) XRD pattern in Fig. 2(b) shows that the main diffraction peaks of TiO2–x in these TCM samples are shifted slightly to a higher angle compared to those of P25, which is caused by the produced OVs [ 40,41 ] in TiO2–x , as evidenced by the EPR, XPS, and spectral analysis results. The Raman spectrum in Fig. 2(c) reveals the presence of carbon in the TCM sample. In addition, typical dominant D- and G-band signals of graphitic carbon were observed for the TiO2–x @C and TCM-1 samples [ 42 ]. The D-band is caused by the disordered carbon from the defects and dangling bonds, whereas the G-band of the carbon graphite phase is caused by the vibration of the C–C single bonds [ 43 ]. The ratios of the G/D band intensities (I G/I D) for the TiO2–x @C and TCM-1 samples were determined to be 1.07 and 1.05, respectively. The relatively higher G-band intensity indicates a high degree of graphitization, which contributes to the conductivity and impedes charge recombination [ 44 ]. The dominant peaks at 147 and 200 cm−1 in the spectra of both the TiO2–x @C and TCM-1 samples (Fig. 2(d)) originate from the E g 1 and E 2g 2 modes of anatase-TiO2–x [ 40,45 ]. For TiO2–x @C, the other peaks located at 401, 514, and 633 cm−1 can be attributed to the B 1g 1, A 1g, and E 3g 3 vibrations of anatase-TiO2–x , respectively, whereas the peaks at 235, 445, and 611 cm−1 can be attributed to rutile TiO2–x . In addition, the clear peaks at 203, 228, 347, 363, 495, and 571 cm−1 in the MoO2 sample can be indexed to the phonon vibrations in MoO2 [ 46–49 ]. These results further indicate that TCM-1 consisted of TiO2–x , MoO2, and a carbon layer. In addition, the broader Raman peak of TCM-1 further confirms the formation of abundant oxygen vacancies [ 50 ], which is beneficial for improving photocatalytic activity [ 51 ]. The SEM images of the obtained photocatalysts are given in Fig. S3. The samples consisted of uniform NPs without any obvious changes. After the formation of MoO2, slightly larger NPs of MoO2 can be observed. The TEM and high-resolution (HR)TEM images of P25 in Figs. 3(a) and 3(b) illustrate the coexistence of anatase and rutile TiO2–x NPs. In addition, clear lattice spacings of 0.351 and 0.205 nm were observed, which can be attributed to the (101) planes of anatase and the (210) planes of rutile TiO2–x , respectively. As for TiO2–x @C, an obvious amorphous layer is observed (Figs. 3(c) and 3(d) ), indicating the formation of a carbon layer. The high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) image of the TiO2–x @C sample in Fig. 3(e) reveals that Ti, O, and C were uniformly distributed in the composite. In the TCM-1 sample (Figs. 3(f)–(h)), carbon layers were observed. These carbon layers can improve electrical conductivity, effectively protect the OVs from oxidation, and improve their stability [ 52 ]. The spacing of 0.213 nm in Figs. 3(h) and 3(i) is assigned to the (210) plane of MoO2. Additionally, the HAADF-STEM image (Fig. 3(j)) and EDS results of TCM-1 further reveal that the TiO2–x , MoO2, and carbon layers were evenly distributed over the sample. To verify the generation of OVs in the TiO2–x NPs, low-temperature EPR was performed to detect the unpaired electrons trapped on the oxygen defects in the photocatalysts (Fig. 4(a) ). P25 exhibited no response at room temperature, whereas TiO2–x showed strong symmetry in the Lorentzian line with g = 2.003, indicating that many OVs had been formed in TiO2–x [ 41 ]. The subtle difference in the g factors is reported to be related to the different positions of the Ovs [ 42 ]. The TiO2–x @C sample exhibited an enhanced EPR signal intensity compared to TiO2–x , suggesting that the introduction of carbon can further increase the OV concentration owing to the relatively easy C substitution or doping [ 43 ]. Moreover, the TCM-1 sample showed a much stronger EPR signal than that of TiO2–x @C, indicating that many more OVs were generated, which may have been caused by the production of metallic MoO2. These results unambiguously prove that carbon and MoO2 synergistically contribute to the generation of OVs in TiO2–x . The abundant OVs in the TCM-1 sample may provide the sample with an increased photoresponse, thus improving the photocatalytic performance. Next, XPS measurements were used to validate the presence of OV defects and the strong interfacial coupling between the different components. As shown in Fig. 4(b), C, Ti, Mo, and O coexist in the TCM-1 sample, whereas only Ti, C, and O are present in the TiO2–x @C sample. The C 1s spectrum in Fig. 4(c) contains three deconvoluted peaks. For TiO2–x @C sample, the peak at 284.8 eV originates from C–C bonds [ 52 ], and the peak at 286.2 eV is assigned to C–O bonds. Based on the literature, the peak at 289.1 eV belongs to C–C=O bonds, indicating the formation of strong chemical interactions between the metal oxides and the carbon layer [ 53,54 ]. The corresponding binding energy for the TCM-1 sample is shifted to 286.4 and 288.8 eV, indicating a strong interfacial interaction. In terms of the Ti 2p spectrum shown in Fig. 4(d), the two dominant peaks at 458.8 and 459.2 eV are from Ti 2p 3/2, whereas the peaks at 464.6 and 464.9 eV can be ascribed to be Ti 2p 1/2 of TiO2–x , respectively [ 55 ]. Moreover, the small peaks centered at approximately 461.0 and 460.3 eV are consistent with the Ti–C bond [ 56 ]. However, no peak corresponding to the lattice Ti–C bond (281–282 eV) was identified in the C 1s spectrum (Fig. 4(c)), confirming that the carbon layer in the TCM sample was elemental carbon rather than TiO2–x to replace oxygen atoms [ 53,57 ]. This result further reveals the strong interfacial interactions between the different components in the TCM sample, which can serve as fast channels for charge transfer, thus enhancing the H2 generation activity. The good symmetry of the Ti 2p signals without shoulders demonstrates the absence of Ti3+ defects in the TiO2–x @C and TCM-1 samples [ 58 ]. Furthermore, compared to the TiO2–x @C sample, the Ti 2p peaks of TCM-1 shifted negatively owing to the higher OVs concentrations in the TCM-1 sample, which partially reduced the Ti oxidation state via localized electrons around the OVs [ 38,59 ]. It is expected that the TCM-1 sample, with the highest number of OVs, will exhibit the best photocatalytic activity for H2 evolution. Four distinct peaks were identified for Mo 3d (Fig. 4(e)): 229.4 and 232.7 eV are from 3d 5/2 and 3d 3/2 of Mo (+4) in MoO2. Two other peaks centered around 235.8 and 231.5 eV are related to the higher oxidation state Mo (+6) resulting from the partial oxidization of MoO2[ 60 ]. The O 1s spectrum in Fig. 4(f) provides more information regarding the OVs. For TiO2–x @C, the prominent peak of 530.3 eV is from lattice oxygen (denoted Ol) [ 61 ], whereas the peak around 530.6 eV corresponds to the OVs (denoted Ov) [ 62 ]. Very weak signals corresponding to adsorbed oxygen are observed at approximately 532.3 eV (denoted Oa). The negative shift of the O 1s signal in the spectrum of the TCM-1 sample was caused by electron migration from TiO2–x to MoO2. The higher relative intensity of the Ov peak (Ov/(Ol + Ov + Oa), 22.6%) in TCM-1 compared to that in TiO2–x @C (19.6%) suggests a much higher OV concentration. Notably, the XPS results further validate the existence of rich OVs, which is consistent with the EPR results. 3.2 Photocatalytic performance and mechanism discussion The photocatalytic H2 generation over the samples was evaluated and compared with the full spectrum. As shown in Figs. 5(a) and 5(b), P25 exhibits a very poor photocatalytic H2 evolution rate (42 μmol g−1 h−1). The TiO2–x sample exhibited almost no H2 evolution activity, which may have been caused by the high carrier recombination rate of rutile-TiO2. Bare MoO2 cannot generate H2 because of its metallic characteristics; thus, it can only act as a cocatalyst. Interestingly, the H2 evolution rate of TCM is improved compared to the TiO2–x sample; for example, TCM-1 achieved 506 μmol g−1 h−1, which is 125.5-and 15.8-times larger than those of TiO2–x (4 μmol g−1 h−1) and TiO2–x @C (30 μmol g−1 h−1), respectively. Next, two important control samples, TiO2–x /MoO2 and TiO2–x /MoO y were tested to illustrate the superiority of the TCM sample. As shown in Fig. 5(b) , no obvious H2 was generated because of the intrinsically poor activity of TiO2–x . This result suggests that both the conductive carbon layer and MoO2 contribute to the promotion of carrier separation and photocatalytic performance. In addition, the contrast sample of TiO2–x /MoO2 showed trace H2 evolution owing to the inferior electron transfer between TiO2–x and MoO2, further indicating the pivotal role of the carbon channel between the different components. Significantly, the optimized TCM-1 sample exhibits a comparable H2 evolution rate to those of previously reported photocatalysts (Fig. 5(c)). The OVs in TiO2–x are easily oxidized during the photocatalytic process, resulting in the poor stability of the photocatalyst. Therefore, the cyclic stability of the TCM-1 photocatalyst was measured over nine successive cycling tests (27 h) to demonstrate the protective effects of the carbon layer. As shown in Fig. 5(d), the TCM-1 sample showed an almost identical H2 production performance during the cycling tests, whereas TiO2–x exhibited decreased H2 evolution as a result of the unstable OVs. This indicates that the strongly coupled carbon layer can protect the oxygen vacancies from oxidation, thereby improving the durability of the sample. Moreover, the structural stability of TCM-1 was demonstrated by comparing the fresh and recycled samples. The similar XRD patterns (Fig. 5(e)), SEM and TEM images (Fig. S4), and XPS results (Fig. S5) for the TCM-1 sample before and after the cycles indicate high structural stability. These results illustrate the stability of the TCM sample during photocatalytic H2 evolution. To understand the underlying mechanism of the TCM-1 sample, we first explored its N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms. As illustrated in Fig. S6 and Table S1, all samples exhibited mesoporous structures. Generally, a large Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area will expose more reaction sites and contribute to the H2 evolution performance. Here, the lower BET value and higher hydrogen production performance of the TCM-1 sample indicate the greatly improved photocatalytic performance of the TCM-1 sample is not caused by the surface area. UV-vis spectroscopy was used to reveal the enhanced photocatalytic activity of the TCM sample. As shown in Fig. 6(a) , white P25 only exhibits ultraviolet light absorption because of its intrinsically wide band gap, whereas TiO2–x shows an obvious red shift, illustrating that the OVs in TiO2–x facilitate visible light absorption. The band gaps of the samples were determined from the Tauc plots. The band gaps of P25 and TiO2–x were determined to be 3.20 and 3.09 eV (inset in Fig. 6(a)), respectively. The narrower E g of TiO2–x stems from the successful introduction of OV defects, as reported in the literature [ 40,62–64 ]. Meanwhile, the visible absorption of the TiO2–x @C sample was enhanced because of the generation of a carbon layer and Ovs [ 64 ]. In contrast, the black MoO2 sample exhibited intense absorption across the entire light spectrum. For the TCM samples, the visible light absorption capacity increased because the light absorption capacities of carbon and MoO2 are high, which is expected to increase the activity. Among them, TCM-1 showed the strongest absorption of visible light, which is consistent with the color change (inset in Fig. 6(a)) and photocatalytic activity. The band gap structure of the photocatalyst was estimated using Mott-Schottky plots. Based on the M-S function shown in Eq. (1), the relationships between 1/C 2 and the applied potential are shown in Fig. S7 and Fig. 6(b). (1) 1/C 2 = 2 × (E – E FB – κ B T/q)/(A 2 ɛɛ 0 qN D) Here, C represents the capacitance of the interface, E FB is the flat-band potential, E is the applied voltage, and A and q represent the contact area between the semiconductor and the electrolyte and the elementary charge, respectively. ɛ and ɛ 0 are the permittivity of material and vacuum, respectively; T is the temperature; N D is the density of charge carriers; and κ B represents the Boltzmann constant. The typical positive slopes of the M-S plots indicate the n-type characteristics of all samples [ 65 ]. From the extrapolation of the x-axis interception in the M-S plots (Fig. S7 and Fig. 6(b)), the flat band potentials (E FB) of P25 and TiO2–x were determined to be –0.83 and –0.91 V versus Ag/AgCl (–0.633 and –0.713 V versus normal hydrogen electrode (NHE), pH = 7). According to previous studies, the negative E FB of TiO2–x is caused by the generation of Ovs [ 52 ]. It is generally accepted that the conduction band of a semiconductor is close to E FB thus, the positions of the conduction and valence band of TiO2-x were determined to be –0.633 and 2.457 V, respectively. Subsequently, EIS measurements were conducted to investigate the charge transfer and separation behavior [ 66 ]. Generally, a smaller arc radius represents a smaller interface resistance between the electrode and electrolyte [ 67,68 ]. The arc radii of the TCM samples in Fig. 6(c) are lower than those of TiO2–x and TiO2–x @C, and TCM-1 exhibits the smallest arc radius, suggesting high electron transfer efficiency. Furthermore, other contrasting samples, such as TiO2–x /MoO2, TiO2–x @C, and TiO2–x /MoOy, exhibited larger arc radii in the absence of carbon, MoO2, and strong interfacial chemical bonds. These results demonstrate that the conductive carbon layer, metallic MoO2 cocatalyst, and strong interfacial chemical bonds synergistically contributed to efficient charge separation. The photocurrent densities of the samples were investigated to support this hypothesis. The stable current density over successive ten turn-on-off cycles indicates the good stability of the photocatalysts (Fig. 6(d)). As expected, the MoO2 sample shows almost zero photocurrent density, which is caused by its metallic characteristics [ 5 ]. Compared with P25, the higher photocurrent density of the TiO2–x @C sample illustrates that the carbon layer can improve charge transfer. For the TCM photocatalysts, the significantly increased photocurrent densities imply that the charge mobility in the TCM samples was enhanced by the synergistic effect of the Schottky junction. Specifically, TCM-1 exhibited the highest photocurrent density, indicating efficient charge transfer and separation. The electron–hole separation efficiency of the TCM sample was further clarified using the steady-state photoluminescence spectrum [ 69 ]. Because the intensity of the PL spectrum is directly proportional to the degree of charge recombination, a lower PL intensity indicates suppressed charge recombination [ 70 ]. The PL spectra of P25 and TiO2–x are compared in Fig. S8. The emission peak at approximately 383 nm was caused by near-band-edge emission. Compared with P25, TiO2–x exhibited a strong emission peak centered at approximately 400 nm owing to the generation of surface Ovs [ 64 ]. The PL spectra in Fig. 6(e) are similar, except that the fluorescence intensity is remarkably decreased for the TCM samples, indicating significantly suppressed charge recombination at the Schottky junction [ 71 ]. The weakest PL intensity of the TCM-1 sample indicates minimal charge recombination, which contributes to the high H2 evolution rate. Similarly, time-resolved photoluminescence lifetime curves were fitted to determine the lifetime of the charge carriers, providing insights into the interfacial electron transfer dynamics. The PL decay profiles in Fig. 6(f) were well-fitted by a two-exponential function according to Eq. (2), indicating that PL decay occurs via two different relaxation pathways. (2) I t = A 1 exp(–t/τ 1) + A 2 exp(–t/τ 2) Here, A 1 and A 2 represent the proportion of two relaxation pathways; τ 1 is the shorter lifetime of nonradiative recombination and τ 2 is the longer lifetime of charge radiative recombination. The average lifetime, τ ave, can be determined according to Eq. (3): (3) τ ave = (A 1 τ 1 2 + A 2 τ 2 2)/(A 1 τ1 + A2τ 2) The fitted parameters are listed in Table S2. Notably, compared with that of P25 (0.49 ns), the average lifetime of TiO2–x (0.62 ns) was longer because the OVs facilitate carrier separation. Moreover, the amplitude-weighted average carrier lifespan of TCM-1 (3.53 ns) is much longer than that of TiO2–x @C (1.22 ns). The extended fluorescence lifetime indicates that more electrons participate in the subsequent H+ reduction, thus promoting photocatalytic activity [ 72,73 ]. Moreover, LSV polarization curves were analyzed to illustrate the superiority of the Schottky junction. As expected (Fig. S9), the TCM-1 sample exhibited the highest cathodic current density and minimum overpotential for H2 generation, implying that the introduction of OVs, a strongly coupled carbon layer, and a MoO2 cocatalyst can significantly accelerate the H+ reduction reaction kinetics [ 74 ]. To gain insight into the intrinsic mechanism of the synergistically enhanced photocatalytic H2 evolution activity, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed. The optimized structural model and total density of states (DOS) of perfect TiO2, defect-rich TiO2–x , and TCM are shown in Fig. S10. Obviously, the Ti-3d orbitals occupy the conduction band, whereas the O 2p states occupy the valence band (Fig. S10(e)). With the generation of OVs in TiO2–x , the density of localized states appeared near the Fermi level, demonstrating increased electrical conductivity and higher electron transport capacity (Fig. S10(f)), which is consistent with previous reports [ 75 ]. As depicted in Fig. 7(a) , the presence of the split-wave total DOS crossing the Fermi level (E f) confirms the metallic characteristics of MoO2, consistent with the UV-vis absorption spectra results. In TCM, more occupied states at the Fermi level (Fig. S10(g))] were observed owing to the metallic characteristics of MoO2. Thus, the oxygen vacancies and metallic MoO2 enhanced the conductivity and charge transfer efficiency; thus, the photocatalytic kinetics were enhanced. Because the Gibbs free-energy |ΔG H*| for intermediate adsorbed hydrogen is an essential index for photocatalytic activity [ 76 ], the |ΔG H*| of the samples are compared in Fig. 7(b). Generally, zero-approaching |ΔG H*| is suitable for photocatalytic activity because the bonds adsorbing hydrogen are neither very strong nor very weak [ 77 ]. Clearly, TiO2–x exhibits a remarkably decreased Gibbs free energy (–0.48 eV) compared to the pure TiO2 sample (2.22 eV), indicating that the introduction of OVs can effectively facilitate the sluggish H2 dissociation on TiO2–x , resulting in enhanced photocatalytic performance. In addition, the introduction of a carbon layer and MoO2 cocatalyst in TCM further decreases the |ΔG H*| to 0.12 eV, which is close to that of optimal Pt (0.11 eV). This zero-approaching |ΔG H*| indicates the great potential of carbon and MoO2 for HER applications. Moreover, the work functions (Φ) of TiO2–x and MoO2 were 5.03 and 5.22 eV, respectively (Figs. 7(c) and 7(d)). Hence, the Fermi level of MoO2 was lower than that of TiO2–x . When TiO2–x and MoO2 were in contact, a Schottky junction formed at the interface. As shown in Fig. 8 . Owing to the higher Fermi level of TiO2–x , the electrons can spontaneously flow to the metallic MoO2 across the conductive carbon layer to achieve new Fermi level equilibrium in the TCM sample, as confirmed by the XPS results. The energy band of TiO2–x then bent upward, resulting in the formation of a Schottky barrier [ 78 ]. Accordingly, a possible photocatalytic mechanism is proposed. At the beginning of illumination, the excited electrons in the conduction band of TiO2–x migrated quickly to the metallic MoO2 cocatalyst because of its low Fermi level and strong electron-capturing ability. The collected electrons in the active sites of MoO2 will reduce H+ to generate H2 because of the preferable |ΔG H*|. The holes in the valence band of TiO2–x react with the sacrificial agent. In addition, band-edge bending and the Schottky barrier height (ϕ SB) prevent the back-transfer of electrons, thereby greatly promoting the efficient separation of e−/h+ pairs [ 79 ] and endowing TCM with excellent photocatalytic performance. To evaluate the effect of the promoted charge separation of the TCM Schottky junction, the degradation of TC and reduction of Cr(VI) were carried out. As shown in Figs. 9(a)–(d), TC and Cr(VI) were barely degraded/reduced in the absence of the photocatalyst under light irradiation. In the presence of P25, approximately 99% of the TC and Cr(VI) were removed within 80 and 20 min, respectively. The kinetic curves (Figs. 9(b) and 9(d) ) illustrate that both the TC degradation and Cr(VI) reduction processes follow pseudo-first-order kinetics (ln(Ct /C 0) = –kt) [ 80,81 ]. The apparent rate constants (k) of TCM-1 were calculated to be 0.01879 and 0.087 min−1 for TC degradation and Cr(VI) reduction, respectively. It has been reported that TC is oxidized into CO2 and H2O by the strongly oxidizing photogenerated h+, •O2 −, and H2O2 [ 82–85 ], whereas Cr(VI) is reduced to Cr(III) mainly by electrons. Notably, the photocatalytic activity of TiO2–x was remarkably lower than that of the P25 photocatalyst because the much higher content of rutile TiO2–x resulted in depressed hydroxyl radicals (•OH) generation [ 86 ], as evidenced by the EPR results in Fig. 9(e). No EPR signal was observed under dark condition for all the samples, whereas strong characteristic peaks of •OH and •O2 − were detected and increased dramatically on visible light irradiation (5 and 10 min). The intensities of the •OH signals (h+ + OH− → •OH−, 1.99 V) with relative intensities of 1:2:2:1 for TiO2–x are lower than those of P25. This result suggests that the introduction of a strongly coupled conductive carbon layer and metallic MoO2 cocatalyst promoted the production of •OH radicals from the photogenerated carriers, which were separated efficiently, and more holes were involved in the formation of •OH radicals. A similar phenomenon can be seen in Fig. 9(f). Compared with those in the spectrum of TiO2–x , the peaks corresponding to •O2 − radicals (e− + O2 → •O2 −, −0.33 V) are more intense, having relative intensities of 1:1:1:1, in the EPR spectrum of the TCM-1 Schottky junction [ 87 ], and no signal was detected in the dark for either. These results indicate that the TCM-1 sample can produce more active species owing to the introduction of an efficient cocatalyst and a conductive carbon layer. The enhanced TC and Cr (VI) degradation activities of TCM-1 further verify that charge separation was promoted. To illustrate the superiority of TCM-1, its photocatalytic kinetic rate constants for TC degradation and Cr(VI) reduction were compared with those of previously reported photocatalysts. As shown in Fig. 9(g), the novel TCM-1 sample exhibited photocatalytic activity comparable to those of many other photocatalysts, indicating its potential for pollutant degradation. The intermediate species of TC photocatalytic degradation were verified by LC-MS under visible light irradiation (Fig. S11). The peak at m/z = 445 is from TC [ 88 ], and there are new peaks at m/z = 459, 444, 427, 410, 333, 318, 274, 102, and 100. According to the literature, TC degradation usually involves hydroxylation, dehydration, deacylation, deamination, and demethylation [ 89 ]. A possible photodegradation pathway is proposed, as shown in Fig. 10 . In pathway I, the TC molecule is transformed into C2 (m/z = 427) by dehydroxylation [ 90 ]. Then, photoinduced free radicals attack the C2 compound, inducing dealkylation to generate intermediate C3 (m/z = 410) [ 91 ]. As degradation continues, product C3 is converted into C4 (m/z = 318) through deamination, demethylation, decarboxylation, and hydroxylation [ 92 ]. With prolonged reaction time, C4 is further converted into C5 (m/z = 274) through decarboxylation and demethylation and, then, oxidized into the small molecule C6 (m/z = 102) by the splitting of the carbon-carbon bonds or to C7 (m/z = 100) by ring-opening reactions. In pathway II, intermediate C8 (m/z = 459) is generated by the hydroxylation and carbonylation of TC and then deaminated to form C9 (m/z = 444). Subsequently, C9 is converted to C10 (m/z = 333) via dehydration, demethylation, deamination, decarboxylation, and hydroxylation under the attack of free radicals. Subsequently, C5 (m/z = 274) is generated through the decarboxylation and hydroxylation of C10 and further degraded into C6 (m/z = 102) and C7 (m/z = 100) through the fracture of the C–C bond and ring-opening reactions. Finally, these intermediates are further mineralized into CO2, H2O, and other small molecules. The toxicity of the TC degradation intermediates was determined using the Toxicity Estimation Software Tool (T.E.S.T.) [ 93 ]. LC50-96hr represents the chemical concentration that causes 50% of Daphnia magna to die after 96 h, and LD50 is the critical concentration that causes 50% of rats to die. As the two values increase, the acute toxicity reduces [ 94 ]. As demonstrated in Table 1 , the acute parameter LC50-96hr for some intermediate products with high molecular weights are low, and they can be classified as “very toxic” and “toxic,” whereas C6 and C7 have much higher LC50-96hr values (> 100), indicating the degradation product is “nontoxic.” In addition, the oral LD50 values of all the chemicals in rats, especially C6 and C7, are very high, indicating that the products are less harmful or nontoxic. Therefore, the degradation products are all low-toxicity substances. Additionally, the bioconcentration factors C2, C4, C6, C8, and C10 were less than 5, indicating weak ecological enrichment effects. In terms of developmental toxicity, C7 is well categorized as “nontoxic” and the indices of C6 (0.51) are close to the critical value of “0.5.” Regarding mutagenicity, the values of the C3, C6, C7, and C9 intermediates were far less negative than the TC value, illustrating that the teratogenic effect was reduced [ 95 ]. Overall, after photocatalytic degradation, the toxicity of the intermediate products effectively decreased. 4 Conclusions In summary, an ingenious one-step in situ phase-transition-regulation strategy was adopted to construct a TiO2–x @C/MoO2 Schottky junction for the first time. The in situ-formed conductive carbon layer not only serves as a charge delivery channel but also protects the OVs from oxidation. Further, the Schottky barrier effectively inhibits the back migration of electrons from the MoO2 cocatalyst to TiO2–x , thus achieving more efficient charge-carrier separation. In addition, abundant OVs can extend the optical absorption spectrum, reduce the bandgap, and optimize the electronic structure to facilitate sluggish H2 dissociation on TiO2–x . Owing to the synergy of OVs, a strong interface-connected carbon layer, and a Schottky junction, the unique TiO2–x @C/MoO2 Schottky junction achieves significantly increased photocatalytic H2 generation, pollutant degradation efficiency, and photocatalytic stability. This study provides a feasible strategy for the in situ construction of an efficient photocatalyst for clean energy and water remediation applications. coredata.dc:description: Limited solar light harvesting, sluggish charge transfer kinetics, and inferior affinity for adsorbed hydrogen species (H*) severely restrict the photocatalytic hydrogen generation activity of TiO2 photocatalysts. Herein, we present a novel TiO2–x @C/MoO2 Schottky junction prepared via a simple one-step in situ phase-transition-regulation strategy. Crucially, the abundant oxygen vacancies in TiO2–x @C/MoO2 narrow the bandgap and introduce defects to improve the photoresponse. The strongly bonded carbon layer not only serves as a fast charge-transport channel to improve the interlayer charge transfer efficiency but also protects oxygen vacancies from oxidation. Moreover, the Schottky barrier effectively impairs the recombination of electrons and holes and promotes the utilization of photogenerated electrons. Furthermore, the MoO2 cocatalyst optimizes the Gibbs free energy for H2 evolution. As a result of the favorable synergy, the resulting TiO2–x @C/MoO2 presents a significantly enhanced photocatalytic H2 production rate of 506 μmol g−1 h−1 compared to those of TiO2–x and TiO2–x @C (125.5- and 15.8-times larger, respectively). Moreover, outstanding stability over 27 h was achieved because of the protection provided by the surface carbon layer. This ingenious design and facile synthetic strategy offer exciting avenues for the design of strongly coupled Schottky junction photocatalysts for efficient solar-to-chemical conversions.

coredata.dc:title: TiO2–x @C/MoO2 Schottky junction: Rational design and efficient charge separation for promoted photocatalytic performance
